text: Florida's primary election, less than a month away.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Early voting kicks off August 10th and will end on August 17th.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: The Escambia County Supervisor of Elections Office is preparing for a high turnout, and they're now making sure all of the voting machines are up to par.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: They put their machines to the test today.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Our Keres Harmon got a behind-the-scenes look at how it all works.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: I did, Sue and Bob.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: They ran a variety of possible scenarios that could all happen on Election Day.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: All in the name of accuracy.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: It's called the Logic and Accuracy Test, where the county tests all of the equipment that will be used for the election and makes sure that it all works properly.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: We run all the actual ballots that we'll be using on Election Day and, again, make sure that those votes are counted accurately.
speaker: SPEAKER_03

text: Going through all of the scenarios that could happen on Election Day, like if a ballot is duplicated or spoiled.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: Escambia County Deputy Supervisor of Election Sonia Daniel gave us an example using a test ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: This is a vote-by-mail ballot, and we know it's a vote-by-mail ballot because it has the V up at the top of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: So this machine should reject that ballot because it was intended for vote-by-mail.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: Ballots can go in head first, feet first, face up, face down, any way that's sideways.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: They even have bilingual and ADA accessible machines for people who may be blind or deaf.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: If I was completely blind, I could use the Braille keypad and I can actually turn the screen off.
speaker: SPEAKER_16

text: Bender says there are 80 precincts in Escambia County and 72 polling locations.

text: We'll be polling about 86 of the tabulators during this primary election.

text: Bender says through this testing, they ensure that it is.

text: The Florida Department of Education releasing report cards for schools and school districts.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Escambia County Public Schools earned a B grade.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Santa Rosa and Okaloosa County districts each received an A. All of the Escambia County Public Schools earned a C grade or higher.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: There were no D or F schools.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: There were nine last year.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Most Santa Rosa County schools earned A's and B's.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Baghdad Elementary and Coastal Connections Academy earned the only D's.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Okaloosa County schools earned A's and B's.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: No schools received a D. Destin High School, Emerald Coast Career Institute and Richburg School were marked as incomplete.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Now, Warrington Prep Academy earned a D this year.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The school was pulled from the Escambia County School District by the state because of failing grades and turned over to a private charter company.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If you'd like to see your child's school grade, you can head to our website, weartv.com, and search Florida school grades to see the full list.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: A Pensacola man is now charged in the death of his wife.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Timothy Kramer was arrested in Santa Rosa County this morning.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: He's charged with homicide and animal cruelty.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: The sheriff's office says Kramer's wife, Rosa Maria Kramer, was reported missing Tuesday night after she wasn't seen the entire day.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Deputies say they found her shot to death at a home on Hillcrest Avenue in Escambia County.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Deputies also found a dog who was shot and later died at a veterinarian's office.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: Timothy Kramer was later located and arrested in Milton.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: He's now in the Santa Rosa County Jail with no bond until he is extradited to Escambia County.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: The city of Milton is looking at a proposal to end its recycling program.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: That program started in 2015.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Assistant City Manager Ed Spears says the recycling program is becoming too expensive.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: He says only 360 residents pay for the service, which doesn't provide enough income.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Spears says the problem?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Most of the loads collected have been sent to the county landfill.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: He says they're usually contaminated.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The program costs us approximately $150,000, but the cost of that is wrapped up in our sanitation budget, where the sanitation employees, the maintenance and repair of the vehicles, the tipping fees, which are about $9,000 just for the recycling, if it has to go to the landfill.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: The program, as far as the fee, only generates about $25,000 a year.
speaker: SPEAKER_22

text: Coming up at 6, WEAR's Sade Ray shares when the program could end and if it could be brought back.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: A life-saving device is helping first responders in Escambia County improve CPR techniques.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: That was last week.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We reported that Central Florida started using automatic chest compressors in all of their ambulances.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Well, as it turns out, Escambia County has used these devices for even longer.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The device delivers more effective chest compressions needed to save someone's life.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Coming up at 6, WEAR's Sarah Gale will have more on other ways the device helps first responders, especially as the nation experiences EMS staffing shortages.

text: A new Florida law increases penalties for people caught driving without a valid license.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The original law applied to cases where a person's license was missing, suspended, or revoked.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Under the new law, people who repeatedly break it face increasingly harsher penalties each time.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The first time is a second-degree misdemeanor, and the second time is a first-degree misdemeanor.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: If a person breaks the law three or more times, they could spend at least 10 days in jail.

text: The Florida Department of Law Enforcement is celebrating the anniversary of the state's Purple Alert.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: That alert was created in July of 2022.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: It helps locate missing adults who may suffer from mental, cognitive, intellectual, or developmental disabilities.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: The alerts are displayed on billboards across the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: You can also sign up to get the alert sent right to your phone.
speaker: SPEAKER_14

text: FDLE says since the program was created, it has helped save more than 435 missing people.

text: Someone recently asked me, do you believe in guardian angels?

text: And my answer is yes, but only for the Christian.

text: And remember, Psalm 103 explains that angels excel in strength.

text: Angels are colossal beings.

text: They are greater in power and might than the strongest of men.

text: However, as strong as angels are, Jesus is stronger.

text: But Jesus is the eternal creator God.
